snippet.textDisplay: I don't care what anyone says or thinks about Nintendo now, they still represent Gaming at its purest. That's not to slight Xbox or PlayStation because I love those, but sometimes you get tired of playing games that try to emulate real life and typical Hollywood action flicks. I appreciate Nintendo still trying to capture your imagination and immerse you into a world of fantasy. Two of my favorite games this gen have been the Ratchet and Clank Remake and Sunset Overdrive. PlayStation and Xbox seem to be hesitant at developing more games like this.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't care what anyone says or thinks about Nintendo now, they still represent Gaming at its purest. That's not to slight Xbox or PlayStation because I love those, but sometimes you get tired of playing games that try to emulate real life and typical Hollywood action flicks. I appreciate Nintendo still trying to capture your imagination and immerse you into a world of fantasy. Two of my favorite games this gen have been the Ratchet and Clank Remake and Sunset Overdrive. PlayStation and Xbox seem to be hesitant at developing more games like this.

snippet.textDisplay: Moses Crosbourne All the other Mario enemies really aren't threats, they just slowly walk back and forth and hope they aren't stepped on. They would be easy to take care of in real life. But the eel? Naw. Imagine swimming down to a coral reef and, peeking out of a hole, is 2 gigantic eyes and a huge set of teeth. Next thing you know, Unagi the Eel is lunging at you, trying to kill you. Terrifying.

snippet.textDisplay:
when i think of this song it reminds me of the innocence.  childhood innocence and the what i have lost.

life can be good.  i'm always so confused by people who say life is good all the time, though.  i am over thirty years old and i only have a handful of memories where my life didn't suck.  one of the times where it didn't suck is when my parents were giving me a stable household and a N64 along with this game, playing it, with gameshark, back when pokemon cards came out and obsessing over collecting holographics.  learning at school becoming well-rounded and alternately going outside in the neighborhood to play with fellow neighbor kids, having routines, life making sense then -- going to middle school -- coming home -- going to sleep, then doing it all over again.  Life was good then.  then it stopped being good and i dont' know why.  

I just wish i knew how to get it back or if it's possible.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's amazing how things can get stuck in one's hand for years and years. While listening to something else, this melody suddenly popped into my head. And I thought "Where do I know this from? Sonic? Metroid? Or was it... nah, probably not Mario."
Fortunately, I remembered this great list of songs...
Funnily enough, I probably have not played this game in probably 15 years and have never consciously listened to its score...
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I can't be the only one who was terrified of that eel as a kid! snippet.textDisplay: I think games being realistic are only nice in the right setting, for example compare something like spyro's AI to banjo-kazooie, where in spyro all the enemies are waiting for you and respond to every move you make, and in banjo the enemies just sit around and only notice you when you're an inch away, the realism kind of adds immersion to the game, or take goldeneye 64 vs. F.E.A.R., the newer AI is more challenging because you can't just wait above stairs, but either way you feel like a badass

What is wrong with CoD? I bet you haven't even played it yet. I've played mario and pokemon for years, and I can't deny, those were the best games I've ever played. But the thing is, is that it's all about the community. All my friends moved on, and started playing cod, so I did too. It's just really fun to play cod together. And I bet that when I'm older, I'll also miss the times I've  
had with cod just like with mario and pokemon. Just because games are different doesn't mean they're bad.

snippet.textDisplay: Yes, I agree. I was teased because I didn't like CoD as much as everybody else, and I was bullied because I liked Nintendo and Mario. My newspaper, The 'Shroom, got ripped up by somebody once when I went to the bathroom. When I got back, it was in pieces. I don't hold a grudge against the Xbox or the PlayStation, but I don't like shooting games because it brings back bad memories. Please feel free too dislike this comment, but it's my own feelings. No offense to anybody.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think that the small levels raised the pace of the game because you get a couple stars and then go onto another level right away. As opposed to lingering on one stage for a while. Also, because of the linear design, you're almost constantly moving to a new area. In Mario 64 There's a lot more backtracking, especially when it comes to the red coin and 100 coin stars.
I would compare Mario 64 to Banjo-Kazooie and Galaxy to Crash Bandicoot. Either way they're both awesome.

snippet.textDisplay: While I also PREFER Mario 64 because of the open levels, the Galaxy games are definitely better. A lot of people would rather have fast-paced platforming than slow-paced platform/exploration. Galaxy is sort of like the 2D Mario games just in 3D. Overall, Galaxy has much better pacing than 64, the controls are smoother (aside from the occasional gimmick stage), and there are a lot more levels with more variety.
snippet.textOriginal: While I also PREFER Mario 64 because of the open levels, the Galaxy games are definitely better. A lot of people would rather have fast-paced platforming than slow-paced platform/exploration. Galaxy is sort of like the 2D Mario games just in 3D. snippet.textDisplay:
Sure, so there is something about Mario 64 that you like better.  I'm just saying that since you prefer 64, it should be better from your perspective too.  

About the nostalgia factor, I guess if nostalgia is truly the main thing that makes you like 64 better, you could claim that you prefer 64 but think Galaxy is a better made game.  But still, from your 1990s perspective, you'd think that 64 is better for you and maybe Galaxy is better for someone who grew up with it in the 2000s.
snippet.textOriginal:
Sure, so there is something about Mario 64 that you like better.  I'm just saying that since you prefer 64, it should be better from your perspective too.  

About the nostalgia factor, I guess if nostalgia is truly the main thing that makes you like 64 better, you could claim that you prefer 64 but think Galaxy is a better made game.  But still, from your 1990s perspective, you'd think that 64 is better for you and maybe Galaxy is better for someone who grew up with it in the 2000s.

snippet.textDisplay: What you've said is reasonable for games that are categorically quite different.  It's possible for you to prefer the games that you play over God of War and still see how others could like it.   But we're comparing two games in the same genre, 64 and Galaxy.  So, if you genuinely prefer 64 over Galaxy, then 64 must have better qualities in your perspective and you should consider it to be a better game.  Others may disagree, but as I said, there's subjectivity even within genres.
snippet.textOriginal: What you've said is reasonable for games that are categorically quite different.  It's possible for you to prefer the games that you play over God of War and still see how others could like it.   But we're comparing two games in the same genre, 64 and Galaxy.  So, if you genuinely prefer 64 over Galaxy, then 64 must have better qualities in your perspective and you should consider it to be a better game.  Others may disagree, but as I said, there's subjectivity even within genres.

snippet.textDisplay: In your example, you'd be saying that the levels in 64 are better than the levels in Sunshine, not that 64 is overall better.  But what about something like gameplay?  That's more subjective and can't really be quantified since different people look for different things and have inherent biases.  So, unless you can somehow correct for your individual bias, which I think is very hard to do, I don't see how you can prefer one game but still think another is better.
snippet.textOriginal: In your example, you'd be saying that the levels in 64 are better than the levels in Sunshine, not that 64 is overall better.  But what about something like gameplay?  That's more subjective and can't really be quantified since different people look for different things and have inherent biases.  So, unless you can somehow correct for your individual bias, which I think is very hard to do, I don't see how you can prefer one game but still think another is better.

snippet.textDisplay: Better in what respect?  I agree that there are objective components of any game that might be better than in other games, such as the quality of the graphics, but to say that a game overall is better requires subjectivity.  I could tell you that OOT is better than Superman 64 since it has better graphics, but you could always come back and tell me that you enjoy the gameplay of Superman better.  If you tell me that one game is overall better than another, that can only be your opinion,
snippet.textOriginal: Better in what respect?  I agree that there are objective components of any game that might be better than in other games, such as the quality of the graphics, but to say that a game overall is better requires subjectivity.  I could tell you that OOT is better than Superman 64 since it has better graphics, but you could always come back and tell me that you enjoy the gameplay of Superman better.  If you tell me that one game is overall better than another, that can only be your opinion,

snippet.textDisplay: I also thought that Galaxy was too easy.  In terms of overall levels, it may be longer, but there are no parts of the game that make it especially challenging, whereas Mario 64 did have such parts.  Even the 100 coin and red coin stars, though occasionally monotonous or trivial, were usually fairly difficult but fun.  Also, if you prefer Mario 64, how can say Galaxy is better?  "Better" is just a matter of preference.  Just because one has more levels or variety doesn't make it better.
snippet.textOriginal: I also thought that Galaxy was too easy.  In terms of overall levels, it may be longer, but there are no parts of the game that make it especially challenging, whereas Mario 64 did have such parts.  Even the 100 coin and red coin stars, though occasionally monotonous or trivial, were usually fairly difficult but fun.  Also, if you prefer Mario 64, how can say Galaxy is better?  "Better" is just a matter of preference.  Just because one has more levels or variety doesn't make it better.

snippet.textDisplay: Obviously it's a matter of opinion, but the majority of people who I talk to who played Mario 64 when it came out and then played the Galaxy games liked Mario 64 better.  The game was more challenging, the levels were better designed, and the fact that you could just use a standard controller and not the annoying Wiimote was great.  I really can't see how anyone couldn't like Mario 64 better after playing both.
snippet.textOriginal: Obviously it's a matter of opinion, but the majority of people who I talk to who played Mario 64 when it came out and then played the Galaxy games liked Mario 64 better.  The game was more challenging, the levels were better designed, and the fact that you could just use a standard controller and not the annoying Wiimote was great.  I really can't see how anyone couldn't like Mario 64 better after playing both.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm starting to become a bit more of a Modern Gamer. I have FPS games, which I enjoy. But as fun as they are, they don't beat the powerful emotion that retro games like this capture. I'd much rather play only SNES or N64 era games for the rest of my life than next-gen games.
People say I'm too young to be a 90's kid, being born in the mid-to-late 90s. But hey, even if I missed out a little, I'm dedicating a large part of me to reliving it as best possible. Games come and go, but these never die.

snippet.textDisplay: The reason video games 'suck' today is because they've moved far from the personal leven that they had before. Now that there's online gaming, pretty much every game, even the single player oriented ones, are done so with a community in mind. In the glory days, with games like OOT and Paper Mario, Donkey Kong 64 and Sonic Adventure, they created a world that people can get lost in. While there are some exceptions nowadays, most games now are flashy and purely for community. I miss the old days

snippet.textDisplay: This comment section is filled with nostalgia-obsessed assholes. Every console generation had at least 3 or 4 oversaturated genres. Remember Space Invaders? You bet that there were a bunch of games that were trying to take its place. How about Tony Hawk, Guitar Hero, Tetris. Super Mario Bros, and Super Mario 64? All starts of oversaturated genres. Hell, 2011 is probably more imaginative than the 90's, with the rise of indie devs and all. It's be nice if you can see games without a rosy tint.

snippet.textDisplay: Am I the only one here who doesn't think video games are dead? Super Mario 64 is my favorite game of all time, but that doesn't mean I don't play new games. Some of my other favorite games are BioShock, Super Smash Bros. Brawl, LittleBigPlanet, Mass Effect, and Red Dead Redemption. There's nothing wrong with getting a little nostalgic when hearing this song (I did too), but to say that there aren't any good games past the N64 era is a pretty bold statement.

snippet.textDisplay: I was born in 1969, and I played lots of video games before this one. However, before this game, I was not interested in Mario games. But Super Mario 64 really amazed me. Now, the other day I went to a video game music concert with a philharmonic orchestra playing arrangements of music from various old Nintendo games (like from the Mario, Zelda and Metroid series). I was quite happy that they played this particular theme. Beautiful!
snippet.textOriginal: I was born in 1969, and I played lots of video games before this one. However, before this game, I was not interested in Mario games. But Super Mario 64 really amazed me. Now, the other day I went to a video game music concert with a philharmonic orchestra playing arrangements of music from various old Nintendo games (like from the Mario, Zelda and Metroid series). I was quite happy that they played this particular theme. Beautiful!

snippet.textDisplay: What makes music like this so impressive for me, is the technical limitations put on the artists trying to make good music for their games. Even listening to the transitions in the song, you can hear solutions and tricks performed to make it work properly. Just incredible.
snippet.textOriginal: What makes music like this so impressive for me, is the technical limitations put on the artists trying to make good music for their games. Even listening to the transitions in the song, you can hear solutions and tricks performed to make it work properly. Just incredible.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm so glad I was born in 1991, meaning I got to experience some of the most amazing games that changed my childhood.  Especially Ocarina Of Time and Mario.

There was so much mystery and curiosity, it was very magical as I saw everything as an adventure around me. Sadly, alot of younger people will never experience this, as I feel sad now that I'm older and don't have that great feeling I did as a kid, but it's something I won't forget.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm so glad I was born in 1991, meaning I got to experience some of the most amazing games that changed my childhood.  Especially Ocarina Of Time and Mario.

There was so much mystery and curiosity, it was very magical as I saw everything as an adventure around me. Sadly, alot of younger people will never experience this, as I feel sad now that I'm older and don't have that great feeling I did as a kid, but it's something I won't forget.

snippet.textDisplay: @PaxAmericana24 I can relate a lot to what you're saying. The music fitted perfectly with the ambience of the stage, but didn't really stand out. I wouldn't have been younger than 13 when playing it anyway, so... I was just using this video as a springboard to launch my ideas. I'm deeply grateful for the memories, but find memory alone somehow unfulfilling. I don't want to live my life in retrospect, losing touch with the fire within. I have to tend to the blaze, in whatever form it burns.

snippet.textDisplay: @Harkz0r Its all true. To be perfectly honest this music didn't phase me so much when I was younger, I found it sleepy and unexciting. It was only after I heard it as I got older that it struck something deeper. As a kid I didn't appreciate the music because I was captive to the 'Magic' of the game. Now, at 21, I am captive to simple memories. Grateful that I experienced the magic when I did though. Heres to hoping our generation builds a better world than whats left to us.
snippet.textOriginal: @Harkz0r Its all true. To be perfectly honest this music didn't phase me so much when I was younger, I found it sleepy and unexciting. snippet.textDisplay: @PaxAmericana24 Hehe, be careful with that blowing, wouldn't want to break anything! Of course you're right in what you say, and I left two other comments after this one that weren't quite as well received. Basically saying that, as we have those memories in the first place, why can't we cast aside all of this wistful negativity and allow ourselves to experience as wholly as we did while young? It won't be the same, as neither are we, but that doesn't mean it can't still be awesome.

snippet.textDisplay: @MathewAlden It's always reassuring to hear opinions like these from a younger audience. It helps to reassure me that I'm not just being hopelessly nostalgic or stuck in my ways. But I think part of the problem is the very nature of -what games are- is changing. Because they are such large-scale commercial projects now, they can be very refined and cinematic in presentation, but can also lack a lot of the spontaneous creativity and charm that comes from a bunch of programmers playing with ideas.
snippet.textOriginal: @MathewAlden It's always reassuring to hear opinions like these from a younger audience. It helps to reassure me that I'm not just being hopelessly nostalgic or stuck in my ways. But I think part of the problem is the very nature of -what games are- is changing. Because they are such large-scale commercial projects now, they can be very refined and cinematic in presentation, but can also lack a lot of the spontaneous creativity and charm that comes from a bunch of programmers playing with ideas.

snippet.textDisplay: By far one of the most amazing songs I've ever heard for a Mario game. I'm 17 now, I remember playing this when I was 4-5. snippet.textDisplay: I have grown up with Mario. Its all I knew as a kid. I remember the day I first jumped the bridge and killed Bowser in SMB1. I remember getting the f*cked up ending in SMB2 (a dream?) and finding all the warp zones in SMB3. Super Mario World literally took me a whole year to complete. SM64 in My opinion is one of the most epic games ever created and it was revolutionary for its time. Every time I see old game footage or hear some of the music, it takes me back to better times. Cheers to Mario!!

snippet.textDisplay: It's hard in the frenetic pace of responsibilities and adult life to forget about everything, especially if your peers don't feel as you do. You flirt with scorn, misunderstanding and rejection. I even had the foresight to predict this as a child, and it scared me, if only momentarily - which is why I decided to make the most of the time I had then. Life's too short to spend caged by your own negative imaginings. Let it liberate you like it once did before.
snippet.textOriginal: It's hard in the frenetic pace of responsibilities and adult life to forget about everything, especially if your peers don't feel as you do. You flirt with scorn, misunderstanding and rejection. I even had the foresight to predict this as a child, and it scared me, if only momentarily - which is why I decided to make the most of the time I had then. Life's too short to spend caged by your own negative imaginings. Let it liberate you like it once did before.

snippet.textDisplay: Even so, that doesn't mean we shouldn't allow ourselves not only to take solace in the memories but also to simply cast aside all the doubts, fears, anxieties and nostalgic wistfulness we carry around with us like so much heavy baggage and just enjoy experiencing things and being alive. How do you think those memories were ever formed in the first place?
snippet.textOriginal: Even so, that doesn't mean we shouldn't allow ourselves not only to take solace in the memories but also to simply cast aside all the doubts, fears, anxieties and nostalgic wistfulness we carry around with us like so much heavy baggage and just enjoy experiencing things and being alive. How do you think those memories were ever formed in the first place?

snippet.textDisplay: It is perhaps one of the greatest tragedies of the human condition that we should ever grow up to lose that spark of magic associated with early childhood but it seems to be an inherent biological truth. I think back to games like Parasol Stars and Mario Paint and know for a fact I will never experience the world through the eyes of a 5-year-old again.
snippet.textOriginal: It is perhaps one of the greatest tragedies of the human condition that we should ever grow up to lose that spark of magic associated with early childhood but it seems to be an inherent biological truth. I think back to games like Parasol Stars and Mario Paint and know for a fact I will never experience the world through the eyes of a 5-year-old again.

snippet.textDisplay: Our grandparents' generation had television just come out and were generally in the war and they are proud of it. Our parents' generation had adversity and are proud of overcoming it with hard work. And our generation has fat people, intolerance, and overall, they care less about their futures. snippet.textDisplay:
@Awesomeggs half the reason why I loved this game is the music.  It totally takes away the typical ADHD mindset of most games and you just want to....

swim across that shore

see what's on the other side of that boat

find where that underwater cave leads

Its also awesome how the music changes as you go underwater....anyway best mario game for me hands down.  It's simply in its own league, calling it a platformer is a misnomer imo.  It's an adventure game.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Awesomeggs half the reason why I loved this game is the music.  It totally takes away the typical ADHD mindset of most games and you just want to....

swim across that shore

see what's on the other side of that boat

find where that underwater cave leads

Its also awesome how the music changes as you go underwater....anyway best mario game for me hands down.  It's simply in its own league, calling it a platformer is a misnomer imo.  It's an adventure game.

snippet.textDisplay:
@MidgeyMe I have to believe that some of my attachment to the Nintendo canon games comes as a result of nostalgia. I'll never get the chance to be 8-12 and play games again, and as a result, I've just about given up hope of attaining similar gaming euphoria.

The way games are marketed and reviewed nowadays, we're taught that EVERY game has some sublime experience to offer to everyone, when in actuality, a lot of pieces have to fall into place for that to happen on an individual level.
snippet.textOriginal:
@MidgeyMe I have to believe that some of my attachment to the Nintendo canon games comes as a result of nostalgia. I'll never get the chance to be 8-12 and play games again, and as a result, I've just about given up hope of attaining similar gaming euphoria.

The way games are marketed and reviewed nowadays, we're taught that EVERY game has some sublime experience to offer to everyone, when in actuality, a lot of pieces have to fall into place for that to happen on an individual level.

snippet.textDisplay:
@BuySomethingWillYa Disagreed. Video games have the potential to become better than ever, with better sound quality, storytelling potential and visuals (and not just graphics, visual style). Some games don't always use this potential, but some games, such as Okami really do.

Retro Nintendo series' are always going to seem more magical to us, simply because they stuck with us, and those memories will never be replaced. I agree with some of your criticisms, but I'm not losing faith yet.
snippet.textOriginal:
@BuySomethingWillYa Disagreed. Video games have the potential to become better than ever, with better sound quality, storytelling potential and visuals (and not just graphics, visual style). Some games don't always use this potential, but some games, such as Okami really do.

Retro Nintendo series' are always going to seem more magical to us, simply because they stuck with us, and those memories will never be replaced. I agree with some of your criticisms, but I'm not losing faith yet.

snippet.textDisplay: @SolidMike84 I'd have to disagree. As a ten year old who grew up with the N64, I was incredibly giddy over the Gamecube's launch (I still remember its smell!) and obsessed over titles such as Melee, Pikmin, Animal Crossing, Mario Sunshine and Wind Waker. At the same time, I was experiencing older titles such as Earthbound, Kirby Super Star and Mario 64 itself. At that time, I never thought the magic was lost...I felt the same magic and nostalgia that older video game fans claimed to have. :)
snippet.textOriginal: @SolidMike84 I'd have to disagree. As a ten year old who grew up with the N64, I was incredibly giddy over the Gamecube's launch (I still remember its smell!) and obsessed over titles such as Melee, Pikmin, Animal Crossing, Mario Sunshine and Wind Waker. At the same time, I was experiencing older titles such as Earthbound, Kirby Super Star and Mario 64 itself. At that time, I never thought the magic was lost...I felt the same magic and nostalgia that older video game fans claimed to have. :)

snippet.textDisplay: I was in sixth grade when this game came out, but I didn't really get to play it (or any N64 game) until I was in college. I didn't have an N64, and none of my friends did either. Eventually I found a used N64 freshman year for 20 bucks (!) and it came with this game, so while I don't really have warm fuzzy nostalgia for the game, it still consumed several weeks of my life.
snippet.textOriginal: I was in sixth grade when this game came out, but I didn't really get to play it (or any N64 game) until I was in college. I didn't have an N64, and none of my friends did either. Eventually I found a used N64 freshman year for 20 bucks (!) and it came with this game, so while I don't really have warm fuzzy nostalgia for the game, it still consumed several weeks of my life.

@JediPrime7 
Our time is passing, my friend. How long before some kid just assumes that Mario started out in 3-D...with Mario Sunshine, or Galaxy? Not to say those two titles are not worth their salt, but Mario 64 and Zelda: OoT were the titles that changed the way I looked at the franchises forever.

@JediPrime7 
Our time is passing, my friend. How long before some kid just assumes that Mario started out in 3-D...with Mario Sunshine, or Galaxy? Not to say those two titles are not worth their salt, but Mario 64 and Zelda: OoT were the titles that changed the way I looked at the franchises forever.

snippet.textDisplay: Ahhh, I remember borrowing the N64 from my cousin. I played this game nonstop. Completing it made me feel good and empty. It was the first game I had ever completed. As I watched the credits roll by, tears came into my eyes and I let 'em go. Today, the N64 has been given away, and no video game music will ever compare to what I consider the 2nd Golden Age of Gaming. (1985-2000)
snippet.textOriginal: Ahhh, I remember borrowing the N64 from my cousin. I played this game nonstop. Completing it made me feel good and empty. It was the first game I had ever completed. As I watched the credits roll by, tears came into my eyes and I let 'em go. Today, the N64 has been given away, and no video game music will ever compare to what I consider the 2nd Golden Age of Gaming. (1985-2000)

snippet.textDisplay: @JediPrime7 You're absolutely right. There are a few good games out there today, but nothing like what we grew up with. Count yourself lucky to be blessed that you grew up in that era and do something to change this one. That's why I make games; to bring beauty and meaning back to an industry that's growing stale.
snippet.textOriginal: @JediPrime7 You're absolutely right. There are a few good games out there today, but nothing like what we grew up with. Count yourself lucky to be blessed that you grew up in that era and do something to change this one. That's why I make games; to bring beauty and meaning back to an industry that's growing stale.

snippet.textDisplay: This was the first game I ever saved up money for.  I was nine-years-old in 1999 and had a Nintendo 64 with Banjo Kazooie and Diddy Kong Racing.  This game didn't have the huge impact on me that Banjo had, but it certainly beats almost any crushing responsibility of being an adult.  I started Mario on the NES and SNES, this is the game that made Mario mean so much more to me.
snippet.textOriginal: This was the first game I ever saved up money for.  I was nine-years-old in 1999 and had a Nintendo 64 with Banjo Kazooie and Diddy Kong Racing.  This game didn't have the huge impact on me that Banjo had, but it certainly beats almost any crushing responsibility of being an adult.  I started Mario on the NES and SNES, this is the game that made Mario mean so much more to me.

snippet.textDisplay:
Super Mario 64 was my very first console game, and my only game for the N64 that didn't have something to do with Pokemon. I was so overwhelmed by the graphics, game in general, everything, I dropped it early on. I picked it up a few months ago with the full intention of finishing it. Still just as overwhelming as it was a decade ago.

(And this is my favorite theme in the game, with the exception of maybe the game select screen~)
snippet.textOriginal:
Super Mario 64 was my very first console game, and my only game for the N64 that didn't have something to do with Pokemon. I was so overwhelmed by the graphics, game in general, everything, I dropped it early on. I picked it up a few months ago with the full intention of finishing it. Still just as overwhelming as it was a decade ago.

(And this is my favorite theme in the game, with the exception of maybe the game select screen~)

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah. Ever played WarioLand: Shake it! For Wii? Admitidaly, it's nothing new, and it's way easy, exept for maybe the final boss, but it's done so damn well... It just FEELS right. The graphics, The music, The controls, they all just come together to make a soild game better then the sum of it's parts.
I supose, in a way, Super Mario 64 was like that too, huh? Exept for the whole "nothing new" thing...
Anyway, Shake it! Feels like some sort of Yoshi's Story sequel: Unorigional, but still good.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Hell yeah. Back then, when you made a game, You had to make it good. REALLY good. You couldn't make your game purely graphical or anything like that, you had to make it make the player feel good. Nowadays, making people "feel good" amounts to doing the same "RunShootTeabag" game we've all played before. Retro, man. It really IS the best nowerdays.

Max Payne series
FFX
Metal Gear Solid series

Yes it was true, for the legends state that this song was composed after a choir of angels sang to the composer.  The sheet music, upon its completion, was bathed in a warm, glowing pillar of light.  And there was much rejoicing.

Recent Mario games seem to have had pretty damn incredible water world music.  Let us also not forget Buoy Base in Super Mario Galaxy.
